comment.author: 57139267@N06
comment._content: The Vandeleur evictions took place between 18 and 30 July 1888.  Mr. French, a photographer working for Lawrence, was present at the eviction of Matthias McGrath in Moyasta on 26 July and at some of the other evictions.  See `The Vandeleur Evictions in Kilrush 1888: The Plan of Campaign' by Noel J. Mulqueen (1988) and `The Vandeleur evictions, Kilrush 1888', by Ignatius Murphy in The Other Clare, Volume 4 (April 1980), 37-41.

comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: My Grandmother's Family ( Liddane ) were evicted from their farm in Rehy, Co. Clare in the closing days of the 19th Century.  Rehy is not far from Moyasta.  The family scattered to The UK; The USA; and New Zealand.  The youngest son, Dennis Liddane, was killed in France on Oct. 10, 1918 about a month before the end of World War 1.  He was fighting for the American Army.  I don't think he was even an American Citizen.  Dennis is buried at the Meuse Argonne American Cemetery in France.  So sad.  The family never recovered from the death of the last born child.

comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: Link below story of Relatives from Irelad and the UK visiting the grave of Dennis Liddane in France. www.clarechampion.ie/index.php?option=com_content&vie...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44911068@N03] As you say, "so sad", especially to be killed so close to the end of WWI. Thanks for all of the above information, and the Clare Champion article is lovely....
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: A more recent article from the Clare Champion. The name Linnane should be Liddane. In Sept. 2011, I was able to get approval from the US Army for the Purple Heart and two WW 1 Victory Medals for Dennis Liddane. The US Army will not be sending the Medals to me in NY til the Summer of 2012. I will be taking the Medals back to County Clare in 2013. I intend to give these Medals to the people of County Clare. The link to the Clare Champion is below. www.clarechampion.ie/index.php?option=com_content&vie...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44911068@N03] Thank you so much for coming back to us with the final chapter of the story for your relative, Dennis Liddane. It's a shame that it will take so long for the Medals to reach you, but I hope that you have a safe journey bringing them home to Clare in 2013.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: Another Article in the Clare Champion. They spelled the name Liddane correctly, this time. www.clarechampion.ie/index.php?option=com_content&vie...

comment.author: 73318702@N04
comment._content: My great grandmother was Catherine Liddane from West Clare.  She lived in Kilrush where my grandmother was born.  There are two Liddane clans: one from East Clare (Sixmilebridge) and my West Clare Kilrush Liddane relatives.  Three cousins live in abd around Kilrush now. Happy 2012. Best wishes for a delightful year. Tom M. Cimbgor@yahoo.com

comment.author: 73318702@N04
comment._content: I would love to hear Liddanes from around the world.  Thx. Tom cimbgor@yahoo.com

comment.author: 44911068@N03
comment._content: I will be coming back to Ireland in 2013 to attend a Viet Nam Reunion at the Adare Manor in Limerick.  At the same time, I have arranged  to donate Dennis Liddane's WW 1  Medals that I have received from the US Army to the Clare Museum in Ennis.

comment.author: 9701496@N02
comment._content: Hello, Just found this thread and I would like to connect with more LIDDANE's originally from west Co. Clare! I know many of my relatives are living in USA (IL, WI, FL) and Australia. My G-G-Grandfather was John Liddane (Tullig, d. 1872); Great-Grandfather was Denis Liddane (Tullig), married to Jane Healy and moved to Crossbeg circa 1884; My Grandfather was Michael (b.1897; d.1982). email me: n_layden@yahoo.com

comment.author: 59302818@N00
comment._content: In the early 1940s I went to school with a lad whose widowed mother had been evicted, I  have a vivid memory of walking home from school with him and seeing their possessions piled up on the grass verge opposite the small two roomed cottage. I particularly remember a Sacred Heart Picture and a Bed Spring lying against the hedge.

comment.author: 93609587@N07
comment._content: Are they stuffing this to set it afire? How about this boy in the forefront, this child doesn't look like he is about to be evicted, is he perhaps with the landlord? What a horrible scene.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/93609587@N07] No, Sheila, the "stuffing" in the windows was to stop the police etc. from getting in...

comment.author: 57139267@N06
comment._content: I have been asked whether I can provide contemporary confirmation that Mr French (and not some other photographers) was present at the Vandeleur evictions.  Ignatius Murphy's precise words are that the Clare Journal of 30 July 1888 mentions "a photographer" [unnamed].  Murphy goes on "One wonders if this was Mr. French whose work can be seen in the Lawrence Collection in the National Library, Dublin,  It is certain that French was present at the McGrath and some other evictions and his photographs ... have left us with a vivid record fo the eviction procedures."  The next footnote cites the Munster News of 22 August 1888, apparently just as the source fo the story that Matthias McGrath broke his handcuffs three times, but it may also mention the photographer(s) present.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pwaldron] Hello Paddy, and lovely to hear from you again! I will try to check in the Munster News of 22 August 1888 to see if the photographer is named...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
